This area is not a good section for a dog park.  Dog runs or parks must be approved by the Parks Commission  If you have suggestions, please contact the Parks Department in writing,. Boston Parks and Recreation Commission. 1010 Massachusetts Ave. Boston, MA 02118 Thank you.
description: Has Jamaica Pond Park been considered for a dog park location? The area just north of Promontory Point is already used by dog owners, and seems an ideal location. I know the city has been trying to fill the need for a dog park. There's a baseball backstop at this spot, but I don't think it's used, and there's one in Olmstead Park that does get used. Therefore, I don't think the community would complain about taking away resources from kids, like they did for the Southwest Corridor Park location. There's some parking nearby. There really aren't any close neighbors, so noise complaints shouldn't be a problem. The adjacent hill gets used by kids sledding in winter, and people lounging in summer, but it seems the flat part above the hill has enough room for a dog park and still enough room for everyone else too.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent. National Grid is installing a new main on your street. The city highly encourages this type of work. It will eliminate possible future emergency leak repairs. The city acknowledges that the construction will cause an inconvenience to the residents. However in the long run the construction is well worth it. Having a street dug up for emergency repairs soon after paving is frustrating for all. With the new gas main installed, the city can feel extremely comfortable that no embarrassing street cuts will happen if it determines to pave your street in the future. Even though the contactor will installing a new main usually for hundreds of feet and in some cases the entire street, we have told the contractor to only post where he will be for the next few days. This will allow more parking on the street. We spoke to the crew and told them they have to follow this requirement . They apologized and said they would comply going forward.  The sign is valid, in fact it tells you who the permiteee is and the contractor doing the work. We apologize for the inconvenience this necessary work will cause. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) Inspector investigated and determined the following. Verizon plans on offering FIOS to the City of Boston within the next few years. Before they can install the conduit, they need to check the existing conduit to see if the new fiber can be installed. This occupancy work is done between manholes. That is what Verizon was doing on your street. The work is supposed to be leafleted and posted. On the locations that the CIU Inspector has observed, the streets had been posted properly. We will talk to Verizon and make sure they are adhering to that requirement 100% of the time. The good news is that the occupancy work of the manholes has been completed. We apologize for the inconvenience the work caused. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Thank you for reporting the incident. I have gathered the necessary information and sent the incident over to the bus yard manager who will be following up with the driver.
description: Today at 7:04 pm while I was headed south on Hyde Park Ave in JP near Forest Hills MBTA station, I witnessed a BPS school bus (MA Tag 37927 / Bus # B546) in the right hand lane squeeze by a bicyclist and force her against the cars stopped along the curb, rather than giving her the lane, as required by law. I audibly heard the cyclist catch herself with one hand against the body of a stopped car to avoid falling over as the bus squeezed past her with mere inches to spare. She was doing nothing wrong, and has every right to share the rose with cars and buses. It was dismaying to see a BPS bus driver making such and unsafe maneuver. I would hope the this driver is given a warning and that school buses are advised to give bikes the lane or pass with at least 3-feet of buffer between their immense vehicles and a cyclist. Anything less is noncompliant with the Mayor's VisionZero the Initiative, I would think.  (Photo attached of the bus stopped at a red light on Hyde Park Ave @ Ukraine)
